abstract.p: Letter from United Hospital Fund president, James R Tallon Jr, on Sept 6 article calls for national effort to provide health insurance for workers

block.p: Reports that rising health maintenance organization costs are forcing businesses to increase premiums or, worse, abandon health insurance plans altogether (front page, Sept. 6) are alarming. The implications are especially ominous here in New York.

Reports that rising health maintenance organization costs are forcing businesses to increase premiums or, worse, abandon health insurance plans altogether (front page, Sept. 6) are alarming. The implications are especially ominous here in New York.

A new study commissioned by the United Hospital Fund concluded that working New Yorkers are more likely to lack health insurance than workers nationally. Last year, 17 percent of New York State's work force -- 1.4 million people -- was without health insurance, as was a startling 50 percent of workers earning less than $20,000.

New York's Healthy New York program, scheduled to begin in January, will provide a new coverage option for companies. But with an unprecedented federal surplus, it is time to rethink this national problem with resources commensurate to the task.
JAMES R. TALLON JR. President, United Hospital Fund New York, Sept. 8, 2000
